page.title: 04Woodchurch Parish Church
page.content: The present Woodchurch church was built in 13th century. It is a strong stone construction which possibly replaced a wooden one from Saxon times. This may be how Woodchurch got its name. The subsidence in the clay has forced the{tower}to have large buttresses.{The spire}is 35 metres high and made of wood. {The West door is only used on special occasions (eg.Weddings, Christenings etc.). The {porch,}made of stone, was added a century later. It has a Holy Water {Stoup}and door that opens onto a spiral staircase leading to the{parvis (priest's room). Octagonal and round {pillars,}made of Kent ragstone, are put in the nave to hold up the roof. The{pews,}made from local oak, were added in 1846. Originally people had to stand. The{pulpit}was altered from three, to a single tier in 1840.
